results.title: Which Films Lead the Biggest Best-Picture Race in Years?
results.abstract: With epics like “West Side Story” and biopics like “King Richard” in contention, Oscar voters have plenty of choices in a category that’s now set at 10 slots.

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from top left: Demi Singleton and Saniyya Sidney in “King Richard”; Nicole Kidman and Javier Bardem in “Being the Ricardos”; Benedict Cumberbatch in “The Power of the Dog”; Ansel Elgort in “West Side Story”; and Caitriona Balfe, Jamie Dornan, Judi Dench, Jude Hill and Lewis McAskie in “Belfast.”
multimedia.copyright: Clockwise from top left: Warner Bros.; Glen Wilson/Amazon; Netflix; Niko Tavernise/20th Century Studios; Rob Youngson/Focus Features

results.title: The Great ‘West Side Story’ Debate
results.abstract: With the Steven Spielberg film coming soon, three critics, a playwright and a theater historian weigh in on whether the musical deserves a new hearing — and how.

multimedia.copyright: Photo illustration by Jennifer Ledbury/The New York Times; Photo by Hank Walker/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images

results.title: Alec Baldwin Says He ‘Didn’t Pull the Trigger’ in ‘Rust’ Killing
results.abstract: The actor said in a brief excerpt from an upcoming interview with ABC News that he had not pulled the trigger when the gun he was holding went off, killing the cinematographer.

multimedia.caption: The actor Alec Baldwin told George Stephanopoulos that he had not pulled the trigger of the gun he was holding that fired, killing the cinematographer of “Rust.”
multimedia.copyright: Jeffrey Neira/ABC News, via Associated Press

results.title: ‘The Power of the Dog’ Review: Wild Hearts on a Closed Frontier
results.abstract: In Jane Campion’s staggering take on the western, her first movie in more than a decade, a cruel cowboy meets his surprising match.

multimedia.caption: Benedict Cumberbatch as Phil Burbank in Jane Campion’s “The Power of the Dog.”

results.title: Detectives Work to Trace How Live Rounds Got on ‘Rust’ Film Set
results.abstract: Investigators are trying to determine whether a supplier who was supposed to provide the movie with blanks and dummies may have sent live rounds.
results.byline: By Simon Romero and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: Investigators are trying to determine the source of live rounds on the set of the film “Rust.” A gun that was  supposed to be loaded with dummy rounds was fired by the actor Alec Baldwin, killing a cinematographer.

results.title: Tony Kushner, Oracle of the Upper West Side
results.abstract: When Steven Spielberg asked Kushner, America’s most important living playwright, to take on ‘West Side Story,’ he thought, ‘He’s lost his mind.’ But he dared.

multimedia.caption: Tony Kushner photographed at the Astor Place subway station in New York City on Oct. 22, 2021.

results.title: The Gotham Awards Find a Big Winner in ‘The Lost Daughter’
results.abstract: The film, adapted from an Elena Ferrante story by the director-writer Maggie Gyllenhaal, took home top feature, among other honors.

multimedia.caption: Maggie Gyllenhaal was a repeat visitor to the stage of the Gotham Awards.

results.title: The Guccis Are Really Not Happy About ‘House of Gucci’
results.abstract: When artistic license collides with reality, which one wins?

multimedia.caption: Lady Gaga as Patrizia Reggiani in “House of Gucci.”

results.title: ‘The Summit of the Gods’ Review: In the (Mountain) Heights
results.abstract: Adapted from a manga, this French-language feature concerns an obsessive climber and a camera that may prove Everest was conquered decades earlier.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “The Summit of the Gods.”

results.title: ‘Torn’ Review: A Climber’s Son Explores His Father’s Legacy
results.abstract: This documentary on the life and death of the mountaineer Alex Lowe demonstrates how unexpected bonds can form around those in grief.

multimedia.caption: The climber Alex Lowe, right, with his son, Max, in the documentary “Torn.”

results.title: ‘Flee’ Review: From Kabul to Copenhagen
results.abstract: A Danish documentary uses animation to tell the poignant, complicated story of an Afghan refugee.

multimedia.caption: Amin, whose family left Afghanistan, as seen in the animated documentary “Flee.”

results.title: ‘Red Pill’ Review: The Horror of a Weekend of Racism and Extremism
results.abstract: Tonya Pinkins is in the director’s chair for this bizarre face-off between political opponents in which rhetoric is the least of the weapons.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Red Pill,” a political horror film directed by the actress Tonya Pinkins.

results.title: ‘Single All the Way’ Review: Cookie Cutter Christmas
results.abstract: This Netflix holiday rom-com rests its family-friendly shenanigans on a display of chemistry that never materializes.

multimedia.caption: Philemon Chambers and Michael Urie in “Single All the Way.”

results.title: ‘The Advent Calendar’ Review: A December Full of Tricks and Treats
results.abstract: In this Christmastime French horror film, a woman struggles against a powerful, old demon eager to rope her into a Faustian bargain.

multimedia.caption: Eugénie Derouand in “The Advent Calendar.”

results.title: ‘Listening to Kenny G’ Review: Good Sax?
results.abstract: Penny Lane’s documentary about the superstar sax player Kenny G shows an artist who can be defensive and self-satisfied almost simultaneously.

multimedia.caption: The saxophonist Kenny G in the documentary “Listening to Kenny G.”

results.title: ‘Silent Night’ Review: Waiting for the End of the World
results.abstract: In this feature from Camille Griffin, a group of friends facing global disaster have one last Christmas dinner.

multimedia.caption: Keira Knightley, center, in “Silent Night.”

results.title: ‘Wolf’ Review: Animal Behavior
results.abstract: This psychological thriller unfolds in a brutal clinic for young people who feel they are animals trapped in human bodies.

multimedia.caption: George MacKay in “Wolf.”

results.title: ‘Benedetta’ Review: Habit Storming
results.abstract: Paul Verhoeven takes us to a nunnery where faith, eroticism and the Black Death make for an unholy good time.

multimedia.caption: Daphne Patakia and Virginie Efira in “Benedetta.”

results.title: ‘14 Peaks: Nothing Is Impossible’ Review: Climbing at a Breakneck Pace
results.abstract: A documentary follows the Nepalese mountaineer Nirmal Purja as he tries to add cultural depth to the sport’s highs.

multimedia.caption: The Nepalese climber Nirmal Purja in the documentary "14 Peaks: Nothing Is Impossible."

results.title: Stream These 15 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in December
results.abstract: The end of the year means a lot of expiring licenses. Check out these movies and TV shows before they disappear for U.S. subscribers in the coming weeks.

multimedia.caption: Philip Seymour Hoffman, left, and Jason Robards in a scene from the 1999 Paul Thomas Anderson film “Magnolia.”

results.title: The 10 Best Podcasts of 2021
results.abstract: Shows about Chippendales, a notorious Hollywood bomb, the search for the perfect pasta shape and the immediate aftermath of 9/11 are among those worthy of your attention.
des_facet: Forever Is a Long Time (Radio Program)
The Plot Thickens: The Devil's Candy (Radio Program)

results.title: Mel Brooks Keeps It Very Light in ‘All About Me!’
results.abstract: The comedy legend responsible for “The Producers,” “Blazing Saddles” and “Young Frankenstein” has written a memoir with the cheer and zip of a one-liner.
des_facet: All About Me!: My Remarkable Life in Show Business (Book)

multimedia.caption: Mel Brooks in “High Anxiety,” 1977.

results.title: Uzo Aduba Adjusts Her Mood With Playlists and ‘The Real Housewives’
results.abstract: The actress talks about sports, her latest film and return to the stage, and why a clean, white pair of Converse All Stars is the shoe for almost any occasion.

results.title: David Gulpilil, Famed Aboriginal Actor, Dies at 68
results.abstract: In a career that began with the film “Walkabout” 50 years ago, he was acclaimed for changing the way Australia’s Indigenous people were portrayed and viewed.

multimedia.caption: David Gulpilil in 2016. An Australian official said that he “revolutionized the way the world saw Aboriginal people.”

results.title: Arlene Dahl, Movie Star Turned Entrepreneur, Is Dead at 96
results.abstract: She had already started branching out when her film career was at its height, writing a syndicated column and launching a fashion and cosmetics business.

multimedia.caption: Arlene Dahl in about 1955. Her column-writing and entrepreneurial ventures kept her in the public eye long after she had left Hollywood and settled in Manhattan.
multimedia.copyright: Fox Photos/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images

results.title: Matthew McConaughey Is Not Afraid to Go Down the Rabbit Hole
results.abstract: “Am I dipping into the spiritual realm and the infinite game of life? Damn right I am.”

results.title: ‘Encanto’ Reaches No. 1, but Moviegoers Are Tough to Lure Back
results.abstract: No simultaneous streaming: “Encanto” or “House of Gucci” could only be seen in theaters this weekend. Even still, some viewers stayed home.

multimedia.caption: The new Disney animated film “Encanto” took in $40.3 million in North America, much less than “Moana” did in 2016.

results.title: When Is a Horror Movie Not a Horror Movie?
results.abstract: When “The Humans” and other new dramas use jump scares and other genre staples, it’s a fair question to ask.

multimedia.caption: Amy Schumer in “The Humans,” a family drama that borrows horror elements.

results.title: Wakefield Poole, Pioneer in Gay Pornography, Dies at 85
results.abstract: He gave up a dance career to create a crossover, and now classic, hit film in 1971 that had both gay and straight audiences, and celebrities, lining up to see it.

multimedia.caption: Wakefield Poole in 1974, three years after the release of “Boys in the Sand,” a landmark film in gay erotica.

results.title: Stream These 7 Productions That Celebrate Stephen Sondheim’s Work
results.abstract: Here’s a guide to films, documentaries and other productions that provide insight into the composer-lyricist’s sly wit and melodic acumen.

multimedia.caption: Hal Prince, director of the original Broadway production of “Company,” and Elaine Stritch, one of the show’s stars, in D.A. Pennebaker's film “Original Cast Album: Company.”
multimedia.copyright: Museum of the Moving Image, via Photofest

results.title: Days Before Dying, Stephen Sondheim Reflected: ‘I’ve Been Lucky’
results.abstract: In an interview on Sunday, the revered composer and lyricist, 91, contentedly discussed his shows running on Broadway and off, as well as a new movie about to be released.

multimedia.caption: In a 90-minute interview on Sunday, Stephen Sondheim was engaged and playfully pugnacious, and gave little indication of being in ill health.
multimedia.copyright: Daniel Dorsa for The New York Times

results.title: On Their Small Shoulders Rest Some Big Films
results.abstract: Five children winning acclaim for their roles in “Belfast,” “King Richard,” “C’mon C’mon” and “The Tender Bar” talk us through their starring turns.

multimedia.caption: Woody Norman with the radio equipment his character’s uncle uses in “C’mon C’mon.”

results.title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include an amnesiac romance and acts of sentient killer robot rampage.

multimedia.caption: Olivia Cooke and Jack O’Connell in “Little Fish.”

results.title: A Refugee’s Harrowing Story, Finally Told Through Animation
results.abstract: Jonas Poher Rasmussen’s childhood friend kept his flight from Afghanistan secret for 20 years. Now, Rasmussen has told his story through the award-winning film “Flee.”

multimedia.caption: Jonas Poher Rasmussen, the director of “Flee,” was drawn to the creative possibilities that animation offers.
multimedia.copyright: Clement Pascal for The New York Times
